Title: Framework - Architecture - Security - Email credentials are stored in Expert Administration for use by Product teams
Description:
This change was implemented in 8110 to unify the email credentials that were used by Product teams; they were previously stored in disparate places around the application under each product's node, but are now unified at the System -> Email node:

We now support individual pages for each product under the Email node:
 
The risks around this are:
- If we make any changes to the way credentials are stored / encrypted, then we require the user to RE-ENTER their credentials so the credentials will be decrypted successfully when they upgrade. 
- We also need to change the corresponding documentation for the release if we're making any changes around this (installation / upgrade I believe, not exhaustive though)
- Product test cases needs to be re-verified to make sure we haven't broken anything (this is up to the product teams to check, we can assist if given test cases but they need to check as part of their smoke tests anyway)
 
Accounts Payable (not tested in 8110 as it wasn't released)

Billing
 

Case
 

Time

Title: Currency control - check the currency control responding to changes in currency
Description: This Test Case was designed to test US 131900.
Steps: Step 1: In Case, go to a form that has a currency control and a field that changes the currency e.g. Liens, Employment, Special Damages, Case Details General. || Step 2: Write in the currency field as it is, with USD already in there. | Expected: The $ sign should be there, and two decimal places. || Step 3: Then change the currency to Japanese Yen. | Expected: The sign should change to the yen sign and the decimal places should go away. There should be a warning saying you cannot use decimals and the number should be rounded. The Save button should be disabled. || Step 4: Change the number to a whole number. | Expected: The warning message will vanish and the Save button will become available again. || Step 5: Try to put a decimal point into the field. | Expected: You should not be able to.

Title: Design Studio - Smart Forms - Group or User variant smartforms can be exported in a package
Description:
We can create variants of smartforms simply by clicking here:
 

 
Depending on whether a user or group is selected, the smartform delta that is created on saving your changes will be set to the User or Group scope.
 
When exporting smartform definitions, the delta of all variants are included in the copy that we include in the package - so any environments that imports the package will receive the base, as well as ALL deltas associated with the smartform.
 
Testing approach
 
Create a new package, then add the smartform to the package.
Export the package, and view the exported smartform definition:
- Check the scope is correct

- Check the deltas for each variant has been included (around the same area as the above screenshot)

- Has appfabric, local

- No appfabric, local
- No appfabric, load balanced
 
 
On each environment:
- Test the workflow has persisted after a minute of idling (local), or persisted on launch (load balanced)
- Test the workflow with delay activities (confirm with Paul again on specific tables to test and construction of workflow e.g. start with task? Start with Delay?)
- Talk to Paul

Title: Users can Upgrade to 82GA and continue to start / complete workflow instances
Description:
Things to test

The oldest line to upgrade from should be 803HF4 / 803HF5, as that is where most of our non-upgraded clients are currently.

Title: Test Chuan's changes around removing computed columns, and ensure Grids return nulls in the application (even if underlying data is 0)
Description:
Expertquery.Matter used to look like this:
 
,CASE [Matter].[CLOSE_EMPL_UNO] WHEN '0' THEN null else [Matter].[CLOSE_EMPL_UNO] END [ClosingEmployeeId]
,[Matter].[PURGE_REVW_DATE] [PurgeReviewDate]
,CASE [Matter].[ASSIGN_EMPL_UNO] WHEN '0' THEN null else [Matter].[ASSIGN_EMPL_UNO] END [AssignedEmployeeId]
,CASE [Matter].[BILL_EMPL_UNO] WHEN '0' THEN null else [Matter].[BILL_EMPL_UNO] END [BillingEmployeeId]
,CASE [Matter].[RESP_EMPL_UNO] WHEN '0' THEN null else [Matter].[RESP_EMPL_UNO] END [ResponsibleEmployeeId]
,[Matter].[OFFC] [OfficeId]
,[Matter].[DEPT] [DepartmentId]
,[Matter].[PROF] [ProfitCenterId]
 
Now It looks like this:
 
,[Matter].[CLOSE_EMPL_UNO] [ClosingEmployeeId]
,[Matter].[PURGE_REVW_DATE] [PurgeReviewDate]
,[Matter].[ASSIGN_EMPL_UNO] [AssignedEmployeeId]
,[Matter].[BILL_EMPL_UNO] [BillingEmployeeId]
,[Matter].[RESP_EMPL_UNO] [ResponsibleEmployeeId]
,[Matter].[OFFC] [OfficeId]
,[Matter].[DEPT] [DepartmentId]
,[Matter].[PROF] [ProfitCenterId]
 
As a result, when we run SQL query against the view, 0 is displayed for CLOSE_EMPL_UNO, ASSIGN_EMPL_UNO,BILL_EMPL_UNO, and RESP_EMPL_UNO.
 
Chuan's changes with the StoredProcDSL now does these conversions on the fly, so in the application it should display NULL (or empty, depending on how the application handles the case).
 
Testing approach
 
Compare use cases from VMAKLITEGG (VNext without Chuan's changes) and Chuan's local.
One use case per application. Include SQL to ensure the target data is 0 when querying the view.
Ensure the data is either empty or NULL in the application.
 
List of application / results...
 
August 23 - build used to deploy environment does not have Expert time working. Everything else is expected to work.
 
Expert Administration:
- None tested, did not encounter any grid / views that would have used a computed column on initial run through
 
Expert Assistant: 
- Found no grids that fit our criteria
 
Design Studio:
- Nothing tested here.
 
Billing:
-Used the following view:  o   Made Admin Editor visible when searching for Bills
o   Run this SQL to find bills with Admin Editor = 0 (select * from ExpertQuery.Bill where PrebillAdminEmployeeId = 0) 
-          Look for the same Bill in App (run this SQL to see Bills in your app: update BLT_BILL set EB_INITIATED = 'Y')
o   Test Result: OK, although I had to use sql to adjust the PrebillAdminEmployeeId to 0 as the UI does not allow me to do so.
 
Budgeting:
- Nothing tested - see below
- Used the following view:
- However did not proceed through as none of the computed columns are expected to be zero if the data was well-formed. This applied for the other views that I saw for Budgeting.
 
Expert Collections
- Used the following view:
o    select CollectionEmployeeId, *
o    from ExpertQuery.BillPayor
o    where CollectionEmployeeId = 0
Test results: OK

 
Entity Manager:
- Chuan tested this and was OK.
 
Expenses:
- Nothing tested - see below
- Could not be tested at this point in time, was crashing for me on saving report with that particular build.
 
MatterWorks:
- Nothing tested
- Found several views, but the computed columns weren't used / exposed inside the application from what I could see:

Rates:
- Nothing tested, see below
- ExpertQuery views found did not have computed fields that were exposed inside the application
 
Time:
- Used the following views and result:
Test result: OK

Title: Having MRU entry in proxy selection does not affect proxy search results

Title: Users can configure logging parameters from Expert Administration
Description:
Logging at various levels will be enabled here:
 

 
Applications are then expected to consume this logging config by logging the messages that meets the logging level criteria.
Applications will start logging as soon the specified log configs are saved.
 
Logging configurations are created with a 7-day expiry date; this is not visible on the page currently (as of Oct 26), but is visible in the table:
select *
from Instrumentation.FWM_Log_Config
 
Questions
- What security resources if any are required for users to add user / application pairs in this grid?
None
- When does logging start? Does the user / application need to restart their application in order for logging to take place? Or can we start something on the fly?
Applications start logging at the specified level as soon the config is saved. No IISRESET required.
- If there is definition for user/application when the user visits the application backstage, will this show? Can users affect logging here?
This is answered in 176189.
 
The available logging levels for toggling follows the Log4net hierarchy: (TRACE, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL) 

 
This does not test the actual execution of logging that consumes the parameters (refactor this when we have information on functionality) - this is covered in another test case

Title: Logging configurations created from backstage appears in Expert Admin, and vice versa.
Description:
Testing Approach
 
Users can setup the user / logging level / application combinations in Expert Admin.
 

 
Users are also able to initiate logging from any WPF application backstage (web applications excluded), by clicking on the start logging button.

This will add a row into the same area in Expert Administration -> Logging Configuration
select *
from Instrumentation.FWM_Log_Config
 
 
 
Check that:
- If user starts a logging session from the backstage of an application, a row is added for the user / application  in Expert Administration
  Confirmed OK. 
- If a row has been added for a user/ application pair in Expert Administration, the user would see logging enabled when traversing to the application backstage.
  Waiting for reply from Jason and Heath.
Currently user sees nothing from backstage. If the user attempts to start logging from application backstage, they will see the following dialog:

 
- If a row has been added for a user/ application pair in Expert Administration, other users can still start logging for the same application from the application backstage, as well as from Expert Adminsitration.
  This is currently working as expected - logging

Title: Logging is enabled at the Session, Activity, and Event levels for each application
Description:
This is the detailed test case that looks at the type of logging information that could be generated by an application, depending on the level that we're monitoring / filtering the log output
 
This should also be the initial holding place for looking at ALL the data that are captured in a log file. May need to refactor this out later on.
 
Session data relates to Application scope generated data. 
- These may exist independently of Activity and Event data... confirm?
 
Activity data relates to business activity / transactions / things that happen inside an application
- These could exist independently...? Confirm
 
Event data relates to individual calls that are usually initiated by Activities to further transaction progress
- These should only exist when paired with Activities - confirm...
 
Bear in mind that the above data is only generated, and thus captured, by our logging mechanism IF the application has opted into the various levels of logging.
 
MatterWorks will be updated to take advantage of the logging changes, but other applications will need to opt in...
 
Things to test:
WPF applications generates logs as expected
Websites generate logs as expected 
Logs are generated at a well-known location (or specified somewhere as per setting)
Check if the PS / support / CRT use cases are satisfied with what we capture in this case
 
 
Testing approach

Title: Users are able to, based on an error log entry, find the log and get further information
Description:
Assuming a user has just encountered an error they could reproduce:
 
And assuming they have the following goals:
1 Get more information
2 Collate logs for escalation to support
3 Setup logging for tracking the issue / related issues later on
 
Assuming the user has the following information as well to search / filter with:
- User
Myself
- Application

- Point of time when error occurred

- Error log from event viewer / application "more information"

 
Goal 1a:
  Possibly the best way to get information is to limit it by application. Go to System monitor via Expert Assistant -> Actions, then go to the Events tab on System Monitor page.
 
Click on the application we want (MatterWorks)

Then click on the associated session that matches our timestamp

And then click on the Logs link to view all associated logs
 
Now we could also look through the business activities or service calls - but this depends on the application hooking into our new logging infrastructure, so we'll instead go to the most common route - the Logs page (where everyone ends up eventually, anyways).

On this page, we can use our data to further filter the deluge of information that's currently displayed to us.
*Note that for logging inquiries, the search uses the terms user has entered in a 'Starts with...' search pattern. So in our case, we needed to look at our error message output from event viewer: "ERROR [1] Attempted to divide by zero.System.DivideByZeroException: Attempted to divide by zero."
Therefore our search term in the Messages box is 'Attempt'. This implementation may change in the future, but for now this is how it works.

Now that we've tracked down the error message, we might want to see if there was anything useful before or after the message. We can use the filters to help us find the messages we want - but we'll need to clear the Message criterion so we pull back all logs. However we'll want to make sure only certain level logs are being pulled back - this depends on the environment default (WARN if untouched), in our case we assume logging had already been elevated when we collected our logs, so there might be something useful from INFO level or above:

If you remember from the previous step, the ID of the log entry we're interested in is 7663. So after everything has been returned, we can now use the column headers to help us quickly narrow down things:

You can sort the date header by descending (assuming you are investigating logs straight after encountering the error), and then scroll down the page until you locate 7663. At this point, all you need is to scroll slightly up and down from this entry to see what was logged prior, and after, your application error!
 
 
Goal 1b: 
  We can also go via the Errors route if we see our error from the stacktrace present on the page:
Since we don't, we click into the Errors heading to see if we can find our error:
 

All log entries at the error level are retrieved, irrespective of the session ID (which specifies the user / application context of the log entry captured).
 
Since we have the error message, we can attempt to narrow down our error log entry using the Message field. As noted above, the search is performed using Start with, so given the error message we'll need to use the word 'Attempt' to retrieve our error message:
 
 
Now that we have our error message, click into the ID to view more information associated:

We now have the session ID to retrieve the rest of the logs - so we should now click into the session ID, and then click on Logs, and follow the rest of the steps as described in 1a. 
 
As you may have realized, clicking through the errors is actually the longer way - the encouraged and intuitive use case / path is through the target application where you encountered your issue!
 
Goal 2a - Collating logs for escalation
 
Inquirys offers two export options; once we're on the page with the logs we want displayed, we can export to PDF or export to Excel (recommended)

Excel is recommended here because the posterity of the logs are preserved; in the PDF version, the column width may prevent information from being read and there is no way to see past the column width limitation. Everything is preserved when exporting to excel.
 
Goal 2b - Optional step and combined with Goal 3.
 
If the user is able to reproduce the issue, then what they can do is to setup the application logging from its backstage:
 

A Caveat: if the issue is of the crashing type - we won't be able to utilize this feature as the backstage logging mechanism relies on the application in a not-shutdown state.
 
If the issue isn't of the crashing type, then we can use this to package the captured logs (in .log format) alongside environmental information all collated inside a zip file, ready to be sent to someone that can help!
 
As per the above screenshot, pressing the Email Support from the application backstage will generate a nice diagnostics package filled with environmental information as well as any logs that could be captured. In our case, since we've already exported the logs we're interested in investigation by the developers, we can simply piggy back on this feature, and attach our exported logs to the email:
 

 
Goal 3
 
If we can reproduce the error (non-crashing) and want to capture all logs associated with the session, then we can set thnigs up via the application backstage .

 
However, if the application in question is crashing upon repeating those same steps, we will need to proceed to Expert Administration to setup logging for the application:
 

In this case, I've created a logging configuration for matterworks so that everytime I use it, the environment will capture any logs generated at the debug level or higher. This will ensure I capture all the things that might help my developer track down the root cause and fix the issue!
 
Any logging config created here will be cleaned up after 7 days - the expiration is available inside the logging config table (INSTRUMENTATION.FWM_LOG_CONFIG) but not visible on the UI. This is by design so the user won't be tempted to try and change the logging period (because this might be running and forgotten on a production system - a bad combination).

Title: Users can adjust settings for event viewer log appender in the Log4Net xml - advanced case
Description:
This test case looks at
- Comments in the Log4Net files we are deploying to the various locations
  - Don't touch default Logging level
  - OK to touch event viewer appender logging level
 
Anything else / other changes we are introducing in the log4net file should be contained here
Ensure this makes it to documentation

Title: Logging summary data can be filtered and used to view detailed logging
Description:
Testing approach
 
The Logging summary data is displayed in System monitor; a new tab has been created to display a limited aggregated view of the captured calls and durations from the logging table, from the prescribed logging configuration for the environment:
 

Each of the headings takes the user to a logging inquiries page that pre-filters the logging data based on the heading, and the date filtered visible on this page.
 
Assumption: These headings should correspond to the Logging inquiries available for selection from the Inquiries: All Lists section.
 
On this page, the amount of records available can be filtered based on time period, and # of records under each heading.
Check that:
- Changing the time period correctly returns the # of rows that matches the criteria, and only logging entries fitting inside the timeframe
- Changing the # of rows viewable will show more / less rows as per the selected setting
 
A separate test case (linked to this one) will look at each of the logging inquiry headings and comparing them against the inquiries page from the ALL LISTS page.defaults what we've selected into the target inquiry page.

Title: Users can deploy with a separate logging database, or deploy logging into Expert
Description:
Testing Approach
 
Two environment configurations to test:
- Set Monitoring database to be same as Expert database
-Set Monitoring database to be a separate database
 
Once deployed:

Title: Design Studio - Activity in Design Studio to run SQL Stored Procedure
Steps: Step 1: Launch SQL Server Management Studio || Step 2: Create a sample stored procedure in SQL using  CREATE PROCEDURE SP_SAMPLE @input INTASPRINT @inputWAITFOR DELAY '00:00:30' | Expected: A stored procedure SP_SAMPLE will be created with a wait time of 30 secs || Step 3: Launch Design Studio || Step 4: Create a new job under the Inquiries branch | Expected: New job with blank fields will appear || Step 5: Enter the Name and Code || Step 6: Choose the activity as SQL Query | Expected: It will diplay fields to enter the query that has to be exectued and to enter the variable where the result has to be stored || Step 7: Enter the SQL query to execute the created stored procedure EXEC SP_SAMPLE 100 || Step 8: Create an output variable to store the executed result and save the Job || Step 9: Make sure the Timeout (found in right pane) is set to less than delay time set for the stored procedure.By default timeout is set to 600 seconds and Click Save and Run button in the ribbon | Expected: The log should show the executed ouput || Step 10: Negative Test Case - Set the Timeout to less that the stored procedure's delay time (less than 30 secs in this case) and click Save and Run | Expected: The log should display timeout error message - "Execution Timeout Expired" || Step 11: Add the created Job in Schedule Manager by clicking Add button in the ribbon bar | Expected: A dialog box should display all the available jobs || Step 12: Search for the job you created and click ok | Expected: A dialog box with job scheduling parameters is displayed || Step 13: Enter the scheduling details and click Ok | Expected: The newly created job should appear under Expert Inquiries || Step 14: Right-Click on the job and select Run Immediately || Step 15: After the job is run, check the logs in the review tab by right-clicking and selecting Show execution log | Expected: The execution log should be same as seen in Design Studio

Title: Preliminary testing on Paul's changes to remove dependence from AppFabric
Description:
Most of the contents here are summarized from the Appfabric independence document I have been curating to document testing and questions asked for the project.
 
Testing approach
 
Paul's changes mainly target the kicking off mechanism of workflows; we've changed from using Appfabric to using our Aderant-rolled mechanism, but the end-result remains the same, we still expect workflows to start. Still, our testing targets end-to-end completion of workflows including initiation, mechanisms including toaster notification, assign / reassign, checking status, and data persistence on completing the workflow.
 
The main test is completing the FO workflow. Starting from publishing the workflow, then kicking it off from expert assistant, and completing the subsequent tasks.
 
The major challenge of testing is actually in the deployment phase; while some problems were encountered as part of the initial set of changes by Paul e.g. during deployment, others were due to the hand-cobbled nature of the binaries provided by Paul. Syncing from master has been hit and miss on most occassions, and it requires several tries and debugging and confirmation with environments in product teams to confirm issues encountered are transient / non-reproducible outside the scope of Paul's changes.
 
Things tested:
- FO workflow - completion end to end. Though initiating the workflow was the main concern, completing the workflow tasks will serve to increase confidence in the things we've done.
- Billing workflow - kicking off some workflows that used the service callback capability - e.g. prepare prebill and the job infrastructure. We need to verify this use case has not been disrupted. Billing team has been very helpful in resolving some environmental issues and incorrect approach in data setup. Eventual outcome was successful with Billing related testing.
- MatterWorks workflow - Due to some problems encountered during billing workflow testing, so I opted to explore workflow capability in other applications. MatterWorks workflow initiated successfully, but there are some problems that appears to be product related which I've communicated with the matterworks team to followup.
- Expenses workflow - Able to initiate and progress to Corrections task due to local setup issues. But workflow could be initiated and tasks received properly.
 
Other products with workflow which aren't tested
 
- Entity Manager if it has a workflow?
- AP
- Collections?
- Budgeting
- Case

Title: Separate workflow database clients upgrading to 82GA are upgraded automatically into a single database
Description:
If the client has previously set their workflow database as a separate one (not contained with the Expert database), when upgrading to 82GA we are expected to combine this into a single database (the Expert database). We will need to support this scenario.
 
Prerequisite:
- Older release environment e.g. 811, or even 80GA), deployed with workflow in a separate database
- Workflow persistence test assets
   - Suspended workflows
   - Active tasks
 
Testing approach
 
Upgrade the environment from the previous release to 82.

Negative test: Hit cancel when the dialog for merging the workflow database is displayed; we expect deployment to stop at that point.

Perform smoke tests against the persisted workflows - expect everything to complete end-to-end
Check Workflow event logging / appfabric event repository equivalent - though this is not part of the changes, would be nice to take a quick look.

Title: DBConfigWizard can be used to upgrade Expert database from any prior versions to the latest version
Description:
Testing approach
 
DBConfigWizard is the utility clients use to upgrade their databases. It must contain all the database changes in the release, and any additional changes will require a new version of DBConfigWizard.
This is the first step that must pass before we can consider deploying an environment.
 
Steps
 
Find DBConfigWizard. The location changes depending on what your current release is. 
For releases older than 81GA: Should be either part of the binaries \ buildall, or provided and built by SCM.
For releases more recent (since Deployment manager became MSI'd): Binaries\ExpertSource\DbConfigWizard
 
Ensure you have no prior versions installed, or else the MSI won't install
 
Once installed, the files will either be:
- Program files - somewhere under the Aderant folder
- AderantExpert\Install\DBUpgradeWizard
 
Fill out your details, and run - waiting for the wizard to finish running.
 
If there are problems, there wil be a log file generated - just follow the path displayed on the dialog.
- It will be helpful for the family developer to fix the issue if they have detailed information on how the script fails. In order to get more information, you'll need to do an individual run of the failed scripts. Either re-run in DBGen or via SSMS. Where the failure is due to .maskederrors or something specific to DBGen syntax, you'll need to re-run in DBGen to reproduce the issue.
 
For database update information tracking, go to the following tables:
CMS_DB_UPDATE
CMS_DB_SCRIPT

Title: Design studio toolbar is installed correctly after a successful deployment
Description:
Things to test
 
Design studio toolbar is Aderant's extension to enable our clients to design workflows in general. There is no other tool that we provide them which facilitates this.
 
The toolbar is installed as part of any success Expert deployment.
 
If installed correctly, upon opening Visual studio you'll see this toolbar available:

The easiest way to determine if this has been installed successfully is to:
- Open a workflow solution
- Observe the activity surfaces - for example the smartform tasks should display the task name, the smart form, and security policy buttons:
You should be able to click into those buttons to invoke the dialogs where you can enter in detailed information / make selections / etc. 
 
- View the Workflow properties
- The workflow should build - CTRL + SHIFT + B or right click on the project / solution and select build.
- There should be no errors when building the vanilla template workflow solutions
- Running the workflow via the green play button - this starts a development workflow instance. If you're using FileOpening as the template workflow, it should start the first MatterIntake task. 
 
If we can get this far, then we can ascertain Design Studio toolbar is in a decent state.
 
 
Additional information / checks
This toolbar is installed as a Visual studio extension, which means if installed correctly, it'll have the following options

With the expert location set to the expertshare location of the customization workstation / current machine. If this is set incorrectly then there will be issues:
- Toolbar may not appear
- Workflow solutions may not build
- Activities do not display / work correctly
- Workflows may not run
 
Case in point / Fringe case: See linked bug 168627, where the client has deployed an environment with an expertshare location that is not C:\expertshare.
In this case, the extension's ExpertLocation will need to be manually set, and visual studio restarted, before the user can continue the workflow experience.

Title: Users can create new sequential and flowchart workflow projects
Description:
Things to test
 
Once we verify design studio toolbar has been installed successfully, the user can create new workflow projects.
 
There are two types: sequential and flowchart.
Apart from layout differences, I am not sure what the technical differences are. (if someone finds out, update this test case/ create new ones and link back)
 
Repeat the process below for both Sequential and Flowchart
 
Some basic information is gathered on creating a new workflow:

More information is gathered in the next step:

Complete the above steps and you'll be able to start developing your new workflow... but you'll want to complete the following steps for extra points.
 
Editing process security: This will allow you to determine which user(s) / groups will have access to interact with the workflow process / instance. This means suspending workflow, terminating / cancelling, or resuming from a faulted state. This will not be tested in this test case.
 
Editing Global task security: This will allow you to determine which user(s) / groups can interact with the task. Those without rights to interact with the task will not be able to complete the task. This will not be tested in this test case.
 
Once you have a working design surface, you're ready to start:
Basic workflow test - logging activity. 
This is the quickest way to check a workflow could be started, run to the end, and complete successfully.
 
 
Some common troubleshooting tips / things to confirm:
 
Confirming the workflow solution has been created successfully:

If an IIS application has been created for the workflow solution, then you're ready to go. This will enable:
- Running of the workflow
- Exporting the workflow into a package for publishing in an environment
 
Confirming the workflow design surface is ready to go:
 
Sometimes after creating a new workflow the design surface is displayed with some errors:

Just rebuild the solution and the surface should be ready. If it doesn't work, check the ExpertLocation setting in Visual studio, and re-install the Design Studio VSIX extension and see if that helps. If nothing works, then ask Paul for help or raise a bug if errors are spotted in event viewer.

Title: Design Studio - Users publish development workflows
Description:
Things to Test
 
In order to publish workflows, the workflow solution must have been opened in Visual Studio once.
 
This creates an entry for the workflow in IIS:

If this is in place, then you should be able to see the workflow when picking the workflow for inclusion into your package:
- Create new package
- On the components filter list, select workflow projects:

Your development workflow should be visible like so:
Select your workflow, then hit export:

Verify the export process has proceeded successfully:

We trust the logs... but we should verify ourselves.
Open the package:
There should be a manifest at the root level.
Deeper, there will be zips for the solution, as well as the exported definition of the workflow

 
The ultimate litmus test is to import the workflow package and publish the workflow, then invoke the workflow (via an action, now that it's published you can't start the workflow like a development workflow), and complete the workflow end-to-end.

Users are able to customize Expert assistant settings for workflow task and process management
Description:
Testing approach
 
Users are able to use Expert Assistant as a focal point for their daily work with Expertsuite applications.
 
Specifically for applications utilizing workflow - we offer a variety of options in Expert Assistant settings to cater for different styles.

The most often used options are:
- New task email
- Reminder email
- Desktop alerts
- Auto open next task
 
Other options are also used but to a lesser extent (Assumption until client data is provided about usage)
 
Options updated take effect immediately.

Title: Users are able to maintain data providers definitions via Design Studio
Description:
Use case: 
 
Users want to modify the data provider at a definition level - this affects all smartforms that uses this data provider.
For example, they only want to allow users to search within users from a specific office.
 
Browse data providers directly via Expert System -> Data provider (you need to know which domain the data provider lives in, though):
 

On this page, users can see the following:
 

Whenever the user attempts to modify the data provider, they will be asked to create a firm version for their changes.
Users are able to revert changes they've made to the data provider via the ribbon menu:

Firm versions and property values are saved in the same location as the system version, with the tables named below.
 
The SQL to access the related data are:
 
select *
from FWM_DATA_QUERY_DEFINITION
where name = 'Bill'
　
select *
from FWA_DATA_QUERY_DEFINITION_PROP
where DATA_QUERY_DEFINITION_UNO in
(select ROW_UNO
from FWM_DATA_QUERY_DEFINITION
where name = 'Bill' )
 
(modify the above to suit your query)
 
In addition to the values you can specify for the data provider properties, you can also specify a filter expression e.g.:
 

Note the above changes will apply to ALL smartforms that uses this data provider.

Title: Users can maintain data providers used on their smartforms via Design Studio
Description:
You can specify the property values via the dialog:

 
This allows the user to specialize the way the data provider works on this specific smartform.
 
For example, if I wanted the employee search to only search for users with the same office as the user running the application:
 

After saving the changes, I would expect data to be saved in the FWM_SMARTFORM_DELTA table:
 
select *
from FWM_SMARTFORM
where NAME = 'Bill Detail'
 
select *
from FWM_SMARTFORM_DELTA
where SMART_FORM_UNO in (
select SMART_FORM_UNO
from FWM_SMARTFORM
where NAME = 'Bill Detail'
)
 
Note the scope of the delta that has been created for the smartform - we expect Firm scope (scope 10)
 
Users are also able to revert to the system definition of the firm by resetting the smartform:

This will remove all deltas and effectively remove the customizations for this smartform.

Title: (Sanity Test) Schedule Manager
Description:
Testing approach
 
Users use Schedule Manager to:
- Manage existing job schedules
- Create new schedules for jobs without schedules
- Review scheduled job runs
 
The existing schedules are grouped by Product, and can be managed visually via different column ordering and grouping functions on the grid.
 
The schedules are stored in
 
select * from FWV_EXTENSION_POINT_SCHEDULE
 
The schedule run results are stored in:
 
select * from FWM_SCHEDULE_AUDIT
 
Check that:
 
- Users can view and manually edit the schedules visually
- Users can perform adhoc runs on schedules, and review the outcome of the scheduled run
- Schedules can be edited / deleted
- New schedules can be created for jobs without schedules
- Jobs with schedules will warn the user if new schedules are going to be added for them
 
Job Verification in System Monitor 
 

 
 
System Monitor should check for the following:
- jobs in error state
- jobs that are suspended
- jobs that are active but have no triggers
- jobs that have stopped running for no apparent reason
 
Review window
Steps: Step 1: Open Schedule Manager || Step 2: Click 'Add' button in the ribbon bar || Step 3: Create new schedule for new created job, and schedule it to run once a few minutes from now. || Step 4: Wait for the schedule to run | Expected: The status should change to 'Completed' after the job completes (may need to click refresh button in the ribbon bar) || Step 5: After the schedule completes, right-click it and select review | Expected: The review window should be similar to the screenshot in the summary of this test case || Step 6: Double click on previous run review | Expected: A log opens up with default log level of 'Debug' || Step 7: Change Log level | Expected: Log level changes appropriately || Step 8: Right-Click and click 'Delete' on that schedule job || Step 9: Create another new schedule for 'TESTSM - Sending Email Job' || Step 10: Change the Occurrence to Daily || Step 11: Change the value in 'Daily Frequency' to 5 Minutes || Step 12: Click Ok || Step 13: Run this query in SQL Server Management Studio to verify the new schedule is addedSELECT * FROM FWV_EXTENSION_POINT_SCHEDULE || Step 14: Right-Click and click 'Duplicate' on 'Sending Email Job Schedule 1' || Step 15: Right-Click and click 'Edit' on 'Sending Email Job Schedule 2' || Step 16: Change the name to 'Sending Email Smoke Test Schedule 3' and select cancel | Expected: The scheduled job's name should not be updated. || Step 17: Change the name to 'Sending Email Smoke Test Schedule 3' | Expected: The scheduled job's name should be updated accordingly with new change. || Step 18: Change the value in 'Daily Frequency' to 10 Minutes | Expected: The schedule triggers information should be updated accordingly with new change. || Step 19: Run this query in SQL Server Management Studio to check the run results of schedules which have run so farSELECT * FROM FWM_SCHEDULE_AUDIT WHERE MESSAGE LIKE '%Sending Email%' | Expected: The query should return some results || Step 20: Right-Click and click 'Delete' on 'Sending Email Job Schedule 1' and 'Sending Email Smoke Test Schedule 3' | Expected: Schedule should be removed without any issues || Step 21: Open Design Studio and delete Sending Email Job under Expert Assistant | Jobs | Expected: Job should be removed without any issues || Step 22: The existing schedules are grouped by Product, and can be managed visually via different column ordering and grouping functions on the grid. || Step 23: Use a combination of different filters to ensure that they are able to work in conjunction with each other || Step 24: Open System Monitor -Verification tab  and Expand 'Schedule Jobs' | Job Verification | Expected: System Monitor should check for the following:- Jobs are in error state- Jobs are suspended- Jobs have missing triggers - active jobs but have not triggers- Jobs have unexpectedly stopped- jobs have stopped running for no apparent reason || Step 25: - Run the DB maintenance Statistics Update Schedule job- Run the DB maintenance FullText Index Reorganize Schedule job- Run DB Maintenance Index Rebuild Schedule job | Expected: Check there were no errors in the execution log within Schedule Manager || Step 26: Run SYS012 Job, and verify no audit record older then 180 days in DB;                     SELECT count(ID)FROM Instrumentation.FWM_AUDIT WITH(NOLOCK)WHERE Date <= DATEADD(dd, -180, GETDATE()) | Expected: SQl should return zero || Step 27: Run SYS019  job and verify monitoring database is shrunk | Expected: SYS019  job completed successfully with no issues. Monitoring DB is shrunk || Step 28: Select any job that takes awhile to execute , and Select 'Run immediately ' option 4-5 times  while it still running | Expected: Only one execution of the job will be triggered, and all others will be blocked. You can verify taht but checking the triggeres entries In DB:  Select * FROM QRTZ_FIRED_TRIGGERSSelect * FROM QRTZ_TRIGGERS || Step 29: In Load Balance Environment, select any job and select Run  immediately ' option | Expected: The job is executed only once by one of the servers and not by both

Title: Users can switch between deploying to separate logging database, or with integrated logging into Expert
Description:
Testing Approach
 
When the user switches from integrated logging to a separate logging database, we are able to transport the logging data to the new logging database because the prior location of stored logging is well-known.
 
On the other hand, when the user switches from a separate logging database configuration to an integrated solution (which is not a recommended configuration to begin with), they will not have the benefit of carrying over their old logs to the new configuration. This is because the old configuration database is now omitted from the environment manifest, and therefore we do not have any way of discovering what the previous database was. (it also wasn't designed this way as there was no requirement to support this)
 
We support users deploying into both configurations:
  
Test that users can deploy to either and hold onto their logs (Do we expect the logs to be transferred between both places?)

Description:
Would be great to get some performance metrics from this test, and see if we need to document this recommendation 
 
Intuitively this is something we would recommend not doing anyway (especially on the production environment), but maybe we need to quantify how bad things could be...?

Again it would be great to have some performance tests back this assertion up. Or make this something we review during the release candidate or sierra environments?

Description:

Testing Approach
 
Users are able to initiate logging for their own user / application from the application backstage:

Which is read from FWM_LOG_CONFIG:
select *
from Instrumentation.FWM_Log_Config
 
Logs are stored in FWM_LOG:
select *
from Instrumentation.FWM_LOG
 
Logs generated in this instance can be searched via the Applications group (With Expert MatterWorks as the filter on Session data)
(http://wsakl001194.ap.aderant.com/Expert_Local/FrameworkServices/SystemMonitor/Events)

Clicking into Expert MatterWorks:
(http://wsakl001194.ap.aderant.com/Expert_Local/ApplicationServices/WebInquiries/#/ExpertSystem.Inquiries.Instrumentation.Sessions?SessionData=Expert MatterWorks)

Users can click into the ID of the user session that matches the timestamp of interest, which will allow the user to further select logs associated with the select session ID:

Clicking into the hyperlinks will provide a filtered view of logs associated with the Session ID, as well as the selected hyperlink as an additional filter e.g. Business Activities:
 

We can then click on Logs (or service calls) to filter the logs by that attribute:
 

Here, we see logs filtered by the session ID AND Activity ID - this allows us to filter for logs at the activity level instead of trawling through all available logs stored in the FWM_LOG table, which could include log entries for other applications and users from the environment.

Title: Logging summary headings lead user to logging inquiry pages that displays expected data
Description:
Logging summary page provides various headings that can default the logging inquiries pages available for users to search logging data:
 
Testing approach:
 
Go to each heading's page, then examine the defaulted parameters on the inquiries page. 
Also check the logging entries displayed on the logging inquiries page to make sure it reflects what we are looking for.
 
Applications: Takes the user to "Application calls", defaults the session type to 1 and the date from the logging summary page.
 
Applications sub heading: Takes the user to "User Sessions" page, defaults the Session Data filter with the selected application under the Applications heading
 
Activities: Takes the user to Activity Calls page. Defaults the date to the selection from Logging summary, and Activity Type to 1.
 
Activities sub heading: Takes the user to "Business activities" page. Defaults the Business activity to the selected activity. 
 
Web Applications: Takes the user to Application Calls page, defaults the session type to 2 and the date from the logging summary page.
 
Web applications sub heading: Takes the user to User Sessions, and defaults the session data to the selected log entry
 
Service calls: Takes the user to Service calls page and defaults the Activity type to 3
 
Service calls sub heading: Takes the user to Service Calls, and defaults Service Call Data to the selected log entry
 
Workflow Activities heading:
 
Workflow Activities sub heading:
 
Errors heading: Takes the user to Logs, and defaults the level to Error.
 
Errors subheading: Takes the user to Logs, and defaults the Exception type to the selected log entry

Title: Old Logging data is cleaned up via a scheduled job
Description:
Testing Approach
 
Confirm how long we keep the logging data first
 
Currently in the SP's, we keep logs from up to 180 days ago for both User session and business data

For general logging data, we keep it according to the following schedule:

 We can quickly check whether certain rows are retained or not by updating the dates on some dummy log entries, and then running the job.
Sample SQL here:
select *
from Instrumentation.FWM_LOG
where SERVICECALLID = '7A209B0B-8DFD-41F2-B01B-B6E10AA4AF25' 
and THREAD = 'Scheduler_Worker-5'
and MESSAGE = 'AutodiscoverLocalException - Unable to connect to Exchange Server using the provided email account: franklin.liu@aderant.com'
 
Let's boundary test. Find the date diff between these log entries and today (this is the age of the log entries)
select DATEDIFF(dd,'2017-11-15 23:01:07.010',getdate())
This returns '1'
 
Then we can add 178 to the dates and run the job - expect the logs to stay:
update Instrumentation.FWM_LOG
set DATE = dateadd(dd,-178,DATE)
where SERVICECALLID = '7A209B0B-8DFD-41F2-B01B-B6E10AA4AF25' 
and THREAD = 'Scheduler_Worker-5'
and MESSAGE = 'AutodiscoverLocalException - Unable to connect to Exchange Server using the provided email account: franklin.liu@aderant.com'
 
The select statement from before should still return our two rows. We can confirm this by running the independent piece of logic in the SP to confirm (our log entries are errors, so using the error retention days below):
SELECT TOP 1 ID
FROM Instrumentation.FWM_LOG WITH(NOLOCK)
WHERE LEVEL = 'Error' AND Date <= DATEADD(dd, -180, GETDATE())
 
Now we add 1 more day to the dates of these two log entries, then run the job:
 
The job rows are still there. Is this a bug? Running the logic returns us no rows, so I guess this is as designed!
 
Lets add 1 more day to the dates of the two log entries again. We would definitely expect the log entries to be removed this time.
Checking with the partial SP logic:
ID's are starting to be returned, so we'd expect our log entries to disappear after running the job. And it did!
The SQL Select statement as well as the partial SP logic select statements returns no results when run.
 
Given the order of magnitude of the # of days we're working with in regards to the logging data retention, as well as the low level of business risk associated, the fact that logging entries aren't cleared when they are exactly 180 days old shouldn't be an issue here.
 
The more important question that we should address / keep an eye out for is the retention date itself in the first instance. Depending on how much the monitoring database grows, we may need to advise clients on different approaches they can take against the amount of logging they want to preserve.

Title: Schedule manager - Database maintenance jobs are now available and runs as expected
Description:
New jobs have now been added in the 82GA release:
 

To determine if they've run properly:
 
Use the attached SQL script, and run the select statements for each section.
Each section corresponds to each job (read the description), and the select script will allow us to obtain a snapshot of the database state prior to running the job.
 
After the snapshot has been obtained, run the job.
We would expect thereafter:
- The statistics / values has changed. 
- The job run has been recorded and it has run successfully or failed (we expect success)
 
With the FullText fragmentation check job, we expect there to be some results indicating an object in the database has fulltext fragmentation.
Running the job would remove this object from the select result
 
With the Index fragmentation script, some object with high fragmentation (on average) will be returned by the select statement; after running the job, we expect the number of results returned to decrease.
 
With the statistics check script, this is harder to ascertain if anything has happened; just pick a popular table out of the list (or several), that has had rows added to it since the last time the job was run, and capture a screenshot of these tables. 
Running the job should update the timestamp at the very least; however the goal of this job is to simply collect and update the statistics for the table objects, so if things aren't quite working then this job has the least impact, in terms of risk that is.

Title: Design Studio - Add Tertiary Text to Matter Data Provider
Description:
In Expert 8.1SP1 Patch 2781, we have added a property to the matter data provider which allows clients to specify the property to use as the tertiary text of the data provider item. It must be a valid property on the MatterSearchResult object.  
 
In this test case, we will add the parent matter display name and code as the tertiary text in the matter search result as an example to show how this field get used.
 
Customize the smartfrom you would like the tertiary text to show in:
1. Open Design Studio
2. Open the standard time smartfrom
3. Click the Client/Matter field
4. Click the data provider ellipsis
5. Scroll down and enter the name of the property on MatterSeachResult you would like to use as the tertiary text, here we use the ParentMatterDisplayNameAndCode as an example
6. Save the changes

7. Open Expert Time
8. Add a new time entry
9. In the Client/Matter field search a child matter and you will see there is tertiary text for this matter with a parent matter
Steps: Step 1: NOTE: Please read the summary page to understand the background | Expected: Understand the background and know how to consume this. || Step 2: Open Design Studio || Step 3: Open the standard time smartfrom in Expert Time | Forms | Time Card || Step 4: Click the Client/Matter field || Step 5: Click the data provider ellipsis || Step 6: Scroll down and enter property on Teritary Text Property field (e.g. ParentMatterDisplayNameAndCode) || Step 7: Save the changes | Expected: The window will be similar to the one shown in the summary of this test case || Step 8: Open Expert Time || Step 9: Add a new time entry || Step 10: In the Client/Matter field search a child matter and you will see there is tertiary text for this matter with a parent matter | Expected: Tertiary text returns in the Matter Search result
